newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Indonesia's Salim may join Manila petrochem group.
newsitem.headline: Indonesia's Salim may join Manila petrochem group.

text.p: Indonesia's Salim Group may take a stake in a proposed $500 million naphtha cracker project in the Philippines, Antonio Garcia, chairman of Petrochemicals Corp of Asia Pacific said on Monday.
"They are looking at a 5.0 to 10 percent stake in the naphtha cracker project," Garcia told Reuters.
Petrocorp is also considering a 10 to 15 percent stake in the Philippine National Oil Co-Petrochemical Development Corp (PPDC) project, Garcia said.

Other companies which have expressed interest in being part of the consortium that will build the plant are Petron Corp, British Petroleum, Sumitomo Corp, Foster Wheeler, Itochu Corp of Japan, and a local consortium, Bataan Polyethylene Corp.
PPDC president Roberto Garcia told Reuters there will be a major announcement from PPDC and Petron in November regarding the naphtha project. He declined to elaborate.
Petron is being offered the biggest stake in the naphtha project at 35 percent.
The naphtha cracker with a capacity of 500,000 tonnes a year is scheduled to be ready for commercial operation by the year 2000.
